explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Mental health is about your mind and how it works. It includes your thoughts (what you think about), your emotions (how you feel), and your ability to cope with things that happen in your life. Just like physical health, mental health is something everyone has.

Mental health exists on a continuum, which means it can range from very good to very poor. On a good day, you might feel happy, calm, and able to handle anything. On a tough day, you might feel sad, worried, or overwhelmed. This is completely normal. Everyone's mental health moves up and down.

Many things can affect your mental health. Big changes, like moving to a new school or parents separating, can be hard. Stressful things, like exams or friendship problems, can affect how you feel. Even things like sleep, exercise, and spending time with friends can change how your mind feels.

Sometimes people do not want to talk about mental health because they feel ashamed or worried about what others might think. This is called stigma. Stigma makes people hide their struggles instead of getting help. But mental health is just as important as physical health. If you had a broken leg, you would tell someone and get help. If your mind is struggling, you should be able to do the same thing.

In Australia, we are getting better at talking about mental health. Programs like R U OK? Day encourage people to check in on each other. For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, mental health is connected to social and emotional wellbeing, including connection to family, community, culture, and Country. Looking after mental health means looking after all these connections.

caseStudy.title: Sam's Up and Down Week
caseStudy.scenario:
Sam is 12 years old and lives in Perth. At the start of the week, Sam felt great. He did well on a maths test and played footy with his friends at lunch. His mental health was good - he felt happy and confident.

On Wednesday, Sam found out his best friend was moving to another city. He felt really sad and worried about losing his friend. That night, he could not sleep well. On Thursday, he felt tired and grumpy at school.

Sam's mum noticed he seemed different. She asked him if he was okay. At first, Sam said he was fine because he did not want to seem weak. But his mum sat with him and said it was okay to talk about how he felt. Sam told her about his friend moving away. His mum listened and gave him a hug. She said it made sense to feel sad about it.

After talking to his mum, Sam still felt sad, but he also felt a bit better knowing someone understood. His mum helped him think of ways to stay in touch with his friend.

explicatoryContent.introduction: When we talk about health, we often think about our bodies - eating well, exercising, and avoiding illness. But what about our minds? Mental health is just as important as physical health, and everyone has it. Mental health includes how we think, how we feel, and how we handle the challenges of life. In this topic, you will learn what mental health really means, understand how it can change, and discover why it is important to talk openly about it.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Mental health is a term that describes our emotional, psychological, and social wellbeing. It affects how we think, feel, and act. It also helps determine how we handle stress, relate to others, and make choices. Mental health is important at every stage of life, from childhood through to adulthood.

An important idea to understand is the mental health continuum. This means that mental health is not simply 'good' or 'bad' - it exists on a range. At one end, people are flourishing - they feel positive, cope well with normal stresses, and can contribute to their community. In the middle, people might be going okay but experiencing some challenges. At the other end, people are struggling and may need extra support.

Everyone moves along this continuum throughout their life. You might be flourishing one month and struggling the next, depending on what is happening in your life. This is completely normal.

Adolescence is a time when mental health can be particularly affected. Your brain is still developing, your body is changing, and you are facing new social pressures. Common challenges during this time include stress about school, friendship issues, family changes, and questions about identity. About one in seven young Australians aged 4-17 experience a mental health condition in any given year.

One of the biggest barriers to getting help is stigma. Stigma happens when people have negative attitudes towards something - in this case, mental health challenges. Stigma can make people feel ashamed or embarrassed, so they do not talk about their struggles or seek help. This is harmful because early support can make a big difference.

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, mental health is understood as part of social and emotional wellbeing. This includes connection to culture, Country, family, and community. Looking after mental health means looking after all these connections.

Reducing stigma starts with talking openly about mental health, treating it as just as important as physical health, and being kind and understanding towards people who are struggling.

caseStudy.title: Maya's Mental Health Journey
caseStudy.scenario:
Maya is 14 years old and lives in Melbourne. She has always been a good student and has a close group of friends. But over the past few months, things have changed. Maya has been feeling anxious about school, having trouble sleeping, and does not enjoy things as much as she used to.

Maya did not want to tell anyone how she was feeling. She had heard other students make jokes about people being 'crazy' or 'attention seekers.' She worried that if she told her friends, they would think something was wrong with her.

One day in Health class, Maya's teacher talked about the mental health continuum. She explained that everyone's mental health moves up and down, and that struggling sometimes does not make you weak or crazy. She also talked about R U OK? Day and how checking in with friends is important.

After class, Maya decided to talk to the school counsellor. The counsellor listened without judging and helped Maya understand that what she was experiencing was common. Together, they came up with some strategies to help Maya cope with her anxiety.

Maya also talked to her best friend, Lily. She was nervous, but Lily was really supportive. Lily said she had felt anxious sometimes too. Maya realised that being open about mental health brought her closer to her friend.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Mental health is a crucial aspect of our overall health and wellbeing that affects how we think, feel, and act. Despite its importance, mental health has historically been misunderstood and stigmatised. Today, there is growing recognition that mental health matters for everyone - not just those experiencing mental illness. Understanding mental health, the continuum of wellbeing, and the barriers that prevent people from seeking help is essential for supporting ourselves and others. In this topic, we will examine what mental health really means and why open conversations about it are so important.
keyPoints: Mental health refers to emotional, psychological, and social wellbeing - it affects how we think, feel, and act.
The mental health continuum illustrates that mental health ranges from flourishing to languishing to struggling, and everyone moves along this continuum.
Adolescence brings specific challenges for mental health due to developmental, social, and environmental factors.
Stigma creates barriers to help-seeking by making people feel ashamed or afraid of being judged.
Reducing stigma and promoting mental health literacy helps create supportive communities where people can seek help early.

vocabulary.definition: A state of wellbeing in which a person realises their own abilities, can cope with normal stresses of life, work productively, and contribute to their community
The range of mental health states from flourishing (optimal wellbeing) through languishing (surviving) to struggling (needing support)
Negative stereotypes and discrimination directed at people because of a particular characteristic or condition
Knowledge and beliefs about mental health that help people recognise, manage, or prevent mental health difficulties
Conditions or attributes that reduce the likelihood of developing mental health problems and support positive mental health
Conditions or attributes that increase the likelihood of developing mental health difficulties
The process of actively looking for and using help for personal problems or psychological distress

analogies.analogy: Mental health is like a garden that needs regular care.
analogies.explanation: A garden can thrive when it gets sunlight, water, and attention, but it can also become overgrown or wilted when neglected. Similarly, mental health flourishes with positive relationships, healthy habits, and support, but can struggle when we face too many challenges or do not have the resources we need.

analogies.analogy: The mental health continuum is like a fuel gauge.
analogies.explanation: Your car's fuel gauge shows a range from full to empty. Your mental health is similar - sometimes you are running on full (flourishing), sometimes you are getting low (languishing), and sometimes you are almost empty and need to refuel (struggling). It is important to notice where you are on the gauge and take action before you run out of fuel.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Mental health is defined by the World Health Organization as a state of wellbeing in which a person realises their own abilities, can cope with the normal stresses of life, can work productively, and is able to contribute to their community. This definition highlights that mental health is not simply the absence of mental illness, but a positive state of functioning.

The mental health continuum is a useful way to understand that mental health is not an either/or situation. Everyone sits somewhere on this continuum, and our position changes depending on what is happening in our lives. The continuum typically includes:

- Flourishing: Feeling good, coping well, connecting with others, and functioning effectively
- Languishing: Going through the motions but not thriving; feeling flat or stuck
- Struggling: Finding it hard to cope, experiencing significant distress, needing support

It is important to recognise that movement along this continuum is normal. A person can be flourishing one month and struggling the next following a stressful event. Similarly, someone who has been struggling can move back towards flourishing with the right support.

Adolescence presents particular challenges for mental health. Research shows that approximately 14% of Australian young people aged 4-17 experience a mental health condition in any given year. Factors that can affect adolescent mental health include:

- Developmental factors: Brain development, hormonal changes, puberty
- Social factors: Peer relationships, social media, identity formation
- Environmental factors: Family situation, school pressures, major life changes
- Individual factors: Personality, coping skills, previous experiences

Stigma remains one of the most significant barriers to mental health help-seeking. Stigma operates at multiple levels: personal stigma (an individual's own negative attitudes), public stigma (society's negative attitudes), and self-stigma (internalising negative attitudes about oneself). Stigma can lead people to:

- Delay or avoid seeking help
- Feel ashamed about their experiences
- Hide their struggles from others
- Experience discrimination in various settings

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, mental health is understood within a framework of social and emotional wellbeing. This holistic view encompasses connection to body, mind, family, community, culture, Country, and spirituality. Understanding and respecting this broader framework is essential for culturally appropriate mental health support.

Reducing stigma requires education, contact with people who have lived experience, and changing the language we use to talk about mental health. Treating mental health with the same importance as physical health is a key step towards creating communities where everyone feels comfortable seeking support when they need it.

caseStudy.title: Jordan's Realisation
caseStudy.scenario:
Jordan is 15 and has always been active in sports and social activities. Recently, Jordan has been feeling overwhelmed by Year 10 pressure, part-time work, and family responsibilities. Jordan noticed feeling more irritable, having trouble concentrating, and not enjoying footy practice like before.

When Jordan's friend Ari asked if everything was okay, Jordan brushed it off, saying 'I'm fine, just tired.' Jordan worried that admitting to struggling would seem weak, especially as team captain.

A few weeks later, Jordan's school ran a session on mental health for Year 10 students. The presenter, who was a young adult sharing their own experience with anxiety, explained the mental health continuum. They talked about how they had struggled during Year 12 but got help and learned strategies that helped.

Jordan realised that what they were experiencing was not just being tired - it was a sign of being lower on the mental health continuum. After the session, Jordan spoke to the school wellbeing coordinator. Together, they identified some practical strategies: setting boundaries with work hours, talking to their parents about family responsibilities, and scheduling time for activities Jordan enjoyed.

Jordan also decided to be more open with Ari. Ari was understanding and shared that they had experienced similar feelings last year. Jordan felt relieved to know they were not alone.

Over the following months, Jordan's mental health improved. Jordan also started using what they had learned to check in on teammates, creating a more open culture within the team.

Workplaces could become more supportive, with mental health considered in job design, flexible work arrangements normalised, and managers trained to recognise and respond to employee wellbeing. Schools might embed mental health education throughout the curriculum, have more wellbeing staff, and create cultures where struggling is met with support rather than punishment. Across all sectors, reduced stigma could mean people seek help earlier, reducing the severity of conditions and the burden on specialist services. A more mentally healthy society might also see flow-on effects like reduced crime, stronger communities, and improved productivity.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Mental health has emerged as one of the most significant public health challenges of the 21st century, particularly for young people. The World Health Organization identifies mental health conditions as the leading cause of health-related burden for young people globally. Yet despite this prevalence, misconceptions about mental health persist, and stigma continues to prevent many people from seeking timely support. In this topic, we will examine contemporary models for understanding mental health, analyse the specific vulnerabilities and protective factors relevant to adolescence, and critically evaluate the role of stigma in perpetuating mental health inequities.
keyPoints: Mental health and mental illness are distinct but related concepts; the continuum model demonstrates that mental health exists on a spectrum independent of diagnosed conditions.

Adolescent mental health is shaped by the interplay of biological factors (brain development, genetics), psychological factors (cognitive development, coping skills), and social factors (relationships, societal pressures).
Stigma operates through multiple mechanisms including stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination, creating significant barriers to help-seeking.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander conceptualisations of social and emotional wellbeing offer holistic frameworks that encompass connection to culture, Country, and community.
Evidence-based approaches to stigma reduction include education, contact with people with lived experience, and challenging stigmatising language and behaviours.

Stigma works similarly - there may be mental health services available, but invisible barriers of shame, fear of judgment, and discrimination prevent many people from accessing them.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Contemporary understanding of mental health has evolved considerably from historical models that dichotomised people into 'mentally ill' and 'mentally well.' The mental health continuum model, developed by researchers such as Corey Keyes, proposes that mental health exists on a spectrum from flourishing (characterised by positive emotions and functioning) through languishing (absence of positive mental health but not diagnosable illness) to struggling (significant impairment requiring support).

Importantly, this model operates independently of mental illness diagnosis. The dual continua model suggests that mental health and mental illness are related but distinct dimensions. A person with a diagnosed mental illness can still achieve good mental health with appropriate treatment and support. Conversely, a person without a diagnosis can still languish or struggle. This reconceptualisation has significant implications for how we approach mental health promotion and support.

Adolescent mental health is particularly complex due to the confluence of biological, psychological, and social factors during this developmental period. Biologically, the adolescent brain undergoes significant restructuring, particularly in the prefrontal cortex responsible for decision-making and impulse control. Hormonal changes during puberty affect mood and emotion regulation. Genetic factors also contribute to vulnerability or resilience.

Psychologically, adolescents are developing identity, testing autonomy, and building coping skills. Cognitive development enables more complex thinking but also increases susceptibility to rumination and negative self-evaluation. Past experiences, including trauma, shape psychological responses to current stressors.

Socially, adolescents navigate increasingly complex peer relationships, social media pressures, academic expectations, and family dynamics. Societal factors including discrimination, socioeconomic disadvantage, and cultural expectations also influence mental health. The interaction of these factors within the biopsychosocial framework helps explain why adolescence is a critical period for mental health intervention.

Stigma represents a significant barrier to mental health help-seeking. Sociologist Erving Goffman defined stigma as a process by which individuals are marked as different and subsequently devalued. Contemporary research identifies multiple stigma mechanisms:

- Stereotyping: Negative beliefs about people with mental health conditions
- Prejudice: Negative emotional reactions based on stereotypes
- Discrimination: Behavioural consequences of prejudice
- Structural stigma: Policies and institutional practices that disadvantage people with mental health conditions

Self-stigma occurs when individuals internalise these negative attitudes, leading to reduced self-esteem and self-efficacy. Research demonstrates that stigma predicts delayed or avoided help-seeking across multiple populations.

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, mental health is understood within a framework of social and emotional wellbeing (SEWB). This holistic model, articulated in documents such as the National Strategic Framework for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples' Mental Health and Social and Emotional Wellbeing, encompasses connection across multiple domains: body, mind, family, community, culture, Country, and spirituality. Disconnection from any of these domains can affect wellbeing. This framework challenges Western individualistic models and emphasises the importance of culturally appropriate, community-controlled approaches to mental health support.

caseStudy.title: Priya's Mental Health Advocacy
caseStudy.scenario:
Priya is a 16-year-old student who has experienced anxiety since early high school. Despite her condition, Priya generally manages her mental health well through a combination of psychological support, regular exercise, and strong social connections. On the mental health continuum, she often sits in the flourishing zone, demonstrating that mental illness and mental health are separate dimensions.

When Priya first started experiencing anxiety, she did not tell anyone for over a year. She worried that people would think she was 'crazy' or that it would affect her academic reputation. She researched her symptoms online but found a mix of accurate information and alarming content. Eventually, her anxiety became severe enough that she confided in her older sister, who encouraged her to speak with their family GP.

The GP referred Priya to a psychologist, where she learned that anxiety disorders are common and treatable. Through cognitive-behavioural therapy, she developed strategies for managing her thoughts and physical symptoms. Her psychologist also educated her about the biopsychosocial nature of anxiety, helping her understand the interplay of genetic predisposition, cognitive patterns, and environmental stressors.

Now, Priya is an advocate for mental health awareness at her school. She joined the student wellbeing committee and helped organise a mental health week that included:

- Educational sessions on the mental health continuum
- Panels featuring young people with lived experience of mental health conditions
- Training for peer support leaders on having supportive conversations
- Distribution of resources about help-seeking pathways

Priya reflects that her experience with stigma initially delayed her help-seeking by over a year. She hopes that by normalising conversations about mental health, other students will seek support sooner.

Her transition from suffering in silence to becoming an advocate demonstrates the power of lived experience in reducing stigma and improving mental health literacy.

extendedAbstract.stem: How might integrating Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social and emotional wellbeing frameworks into mainstream mental health services transform both outcomes for Indigenous Australians and the broader understanding of mental health?

This cultural alignment is associated with better engagement and outcomes. For the broader mental health system, it could challenge the reductionist focus on individual pathology and expand understanding to include relational and environmental factors. Concepts like connection to Country and community might inform new preventive approaches emphasising belonging and connection. However, genuine integration requires power-sharing with Indigenous communities and avoiding appropriation of concepts without structural change. It would require training mainstream providers in cultural safety and challenging embedded structural stigma. Done well, it could create more holistic, culturally diverse mental health services that benefit everyone while specifically addressing the historical and ongoing impacts of colonisation on Indigenous mental health.

explicatoryContent.introduction: The conceptualisation of mental health is contested terrain, shaped by historical, cultural, and political forces. From the moral and religious frameworks of pre-modern societies, through the medicalisation of 'madness' in the 18th and 19th centuries, to contemporary biopsychosocial and recovery-oriented models, understandings of mental health reflect broader epistemological assumptions about the nature of human experience. In this topic, we will critically examine these frameworks, analyse the socioecological production of mental health and illness, and evaluate the mechanisms through which stigma operates as both a social process and structural barrier. This analysis has significant implications for how we design interventions, allocate resources, and create conditions for wellbeing.
keyPoints: Conceptualisations of mental health are historically and culturally contingent; the dual continua and recovery models represent shifts from deficit-based to strengths-based frameworks.
Adolescent mental health is produced through socioecological processes, with factors operating at individual, interpersonal, institutional, community, and macrosocial levels.
Stigma is best understood as a social process involving labelling, stereotyping, separation, status loss, and discrimination in the context of power asymmetries.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social and emotional wellbeing frameworks constitute distinct ontological positions that challenge Western individualistic assumptions.
Effective mental health promotion requires multi-level interventions addressing individual skills, social environments, and structural determinants.

A framework conceptualising mental health and mental illness as related but distinct dimensions
An approach emphasising that people with mental illness can live meaningful lives through personal growth rather than cure

analogies.analogy: Different conceptualisations of mental health are like different maps of the same territory.
analogies.explanation: A topographical map shows terrain; a political map shows boundaries; an indigenous map might show songlines and sacred sites. Each reveals something while obscuring other aspects. Similarly, biomedical models, social models, and Indigenous frameworks each illuminate different aspects of mental health while reflecting particular epistemological commitments. Sophisticated understanding requires capacity to work across multiple 'maps' while recognising what each includes and excludes.

analogies.analogy: Stigma operates like compound interest on disadvantage.
analogies.explanation: Financial compound interest accumulates over time, with interest earning interest. Stigma operates similarly - initial labelling leads to discrimination, which affects opportunities, which reinforces the original stereotype, which leads to more discrimination. Over time, this compounds into significant disadvantage. Understanding this accumulation helps explain why brief interventions have limited effect against entrenched stigma.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
The history of mental health conceptualisation reveals the historically contingent nature of seemingly objective categories. The medicalisation of mental distress in the 18th and 19th centuries, documented by scholars such as Michel Foucault, transformed experiences previously understood through moral or religious frameworks into medical conditions requiring professional intervention. While this shift brought benefits including systematic research and treatment development, it also pathologised experiences that might be understood differently in other contexts.

Contemporary frameworks attempt to move beyond simple pathology. Corey Keyes' dual continua model proposes that mental health (flourishing to languishing) and mental illness (present or absent) are related but distinct dimensions. This has significant implications: it suggests that mental illness does not preclude flourishing, and that the absence of mental illness does not guarantee wellbeing. The recovery model, developed largely through consumer advocacy, emphasises that recovery is a personal process of developing meaning and purpose rather than clinical 'cure.'

The socioecological model provides a framework for understanding how mental health is produced through multiple interacting levels:

- Individual level: Genetic predisposition, temperament, cognitive patterns, coping skills
- Interpersonal level: Family relationships, peer relationships, social support
- Institutional level: Schools, workplaces, health services and their cultures and policies
- Community level: Neighbourhood characteristics, social cohesion, collective efficacy
- Macrosocial level: Economic conditions, policies, cultural values, discrimination

These levels interact dynamically. Macrosocial factors like economic inequality shape community resources and institutional practices, which influence interpersonal relationships and individual experiences. Understanding this ecology is essential for designing effective interventions that go beyond individual-level approaches.

Link and Phelan's conceptualisation of stigma as a social process identifies five interrelated components: labelling (identifying and marking difference), stereotyping (linking labels to undesirable characteristics), separation (creating 'us' and 'them' distinctions), status loss (devaluation of labelled groups), and discrimination (behavioural consequences). Crucially, they argue that stigma depends on power asymmetries - the ability to label, discriminate against, and materially disadvantage others. This analysis suggests that stigma reduction requires not just attitude change but power redistribution.

Structural stigma represents perhaps the most insidious form of discrimination. It includes policies that discriminate against people with mental health conditions, resource allocation that underfunds mental health services, and institutional practices that exclude or disadvantage labelled individuals. Because structural stigma is embedded in 'business as usual,' it can perpetuate inequity without explicit prejudice from individuals.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social and emotional wellbeing frameworks represent distinct ontological positions rather than variations on Western models. The National Strategic Framework for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples' Mental Health and Social and Emotional Wellbeing identifies domains including body, mind, family, community, culture, Country, and spirituality, with the individual at the centre of interconnecting relationships. Critically, these frameworks understand wellbeing as fundamentally relational and collective rather than individual. They also name colonisation and its ongoing effects, including intergenerational trauma, racism, and disconnection from Country and culture, as factors affecting contemporary mental health.

These frameworks have implications beyond Indigenous contexts. They challenge Western assumptions about individualism and mind-body dualism, highlight the importance of connection and belonging, and demonstrate that different cultural traditions have developed sophisticated understandings of wellbeing that deserve recognition within mental health discourse.

caseStudy.title: Dr. Williams' Structural Intervention
caseStudy.scenario:
Dr. Sarah Williams is a health policy researcher who has spent her career analysing mental health systems. Early in her career, she focused on stigma reduction programs, but over time became frustrated by the limited impact of educational interventions. Her research led her to analyse stigma as a structural phenomenon.

Dr. Williams documented how structural stigma operates in multiple domains. In insurance, she found that many policies provided inferior coverage for mental health compared to physical health. In employment, workplace policies often penalised mental health-related absences more than physical illness absences. In housing, people with mental health histories faced discrimination in rental applications. In education, disciplinary policies disproportionately punished students whose behaviour was related to mental health conditions.

She also analysed how structural stigma interacts with other forms of discrimination. Young people from low socioeconomic backgrounds faced compounding disadvantages: fewer mental health resources in their communities, more environmental stressors, and greater stigma about help-seeking. Indigenous young people faced the intersection of mental health stigma with ongoing racism and the legacy of colonisation.

Dr. Williams shifted her advocacy from individual stigma reduction to structural reform. She worked with policymakers on mental health parity legislation requiring equal insurance coverage. She developed workplace guidelines for mental health-informed policies. She partnered with housing advocates to challenge discriminatory practices. She collaborated with education systems on alternatives to punitive discipline for students with mental health needs.

Dr. Williams acknowledges that structural change is slow and politically contested. But she argues that without addressing the policies and practices that systematically disadvantage people with mental health conditions, individual-level interventions will always be swimming against the tide.

remember.stem: According to Link and Phelan's conceptualisation, which component is essential for stigma to produce social inequity?

options.text: Stereotyping alone
options.feedback: Not quite. While stereotyping is one component, Link and Phelan argue that power is essential for stigma to produce inequity - without power, labelling and stereotyping cannot lead to discrimination and material disadvantage.

options.text: Power asymmetries
options.feedback: Correct! Link and Phelan argue that stigma depends on power - the ability to label others, discriminate against them, and create material disadvantage. Without power asymmetries, stigma cannot produce social inequity.

options.text: Individual attitudes
options.feedback: Not quite. While attitudes contribute to stigma, Link and Phelan's key insight is that power is essential - stigma produces inequity when those with power can label, discriminate, and disadvantage others.

options.text: Public awareness campaigns
options.feedback: Not quite. This is an intervention against stigma, not a component of stigma. Link and Phelan identify labelling, stereotyping, separation, status loss, discrimination, and power as key components.

remember.stem: Which level of the socioecological model would include school policies about mental health absences?

options.text: Individual level
options.feedback: Not quite. Individual level factors are characteristics of the person such as genetics, temperament, and coping skills. School policies operate at the institutional level.

options.text: Interpersonal level
options.feedback: Not quite. Interpersonal level includes relationships like family and peer relationships. School policies are institutional factors.

options.text: Institutional level
options.feedback: Correct! The institutional level includes organisations like schools, workplaces, and health services and their policies and cultures. School policies about mental health absences operate at this level.

options.text: Macrosocial level
options.feedback: Not quite. Macrosocial level includes broader factors like economic conditions, national policies, and cultural values. School policies are more specific, operating at the institutional level.

understand.stem: Explain how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social and emotional wellbeing frameworks challenge the assumptions of Western individualised mental health models.
understand.rubric: A good answer identifies key assumptions of Western models (individualism, mind-body separation, pathology focus) and explains how SEWB frameworks offer alternative conceptualisations (relational wellbeing, holistic domains, connection to Country and culture).

apply.stem: Using the socioecological model, analyse how economic recession might affect adolescent mental health through multiple levels.
apply.rubric: A good answer traces effects through macrosocial (economic stress, policy changes), community (service reductions, unemployment), institutional (school resource cuts), interpersonal (family stress, peer competition), and individual (anxiety, reduced access to support) levels.

analyse.rubric: A good answer analyses how structural stigma is embedded in policies and practices, operates independently of individual attitudes, and produces material disadvantage. It explains why changing attitudes may not change outcomes without addressing structural factors.

evaluate.rubric: A strong answer evaluates strengths (moves beyond deficit model, allows for flourishing with illness, supports recovery approach) and limitations (may maintain categorical thinking, developed in Western context, may not capture cultural diversity).

create.stem: Design a comprehensive multi-level mental health promotion strategy for an Australian secondary school that addresses individual, interpersonal, institutional, and community factors. Draw on the socioecological model and evidence about stigma reduction. Consider cultural diversity and include evaluation components.
create.rubric: An excellent response demonstrates sophisticated understanding of socioecological frameworks, incorporates evidence-based strategies at each level, addresses structural as well as individual factors, shows cultural responsiveness, and includes realistic evaluation methods.

unistructural.stem: Identify ONE way that the recovery model differs from traditional medical models of mental illness.
unistructural.modelResponse: One key difference is that the recovery model emphasises personal meaning and quality of life rather than symptom elimination. While medical models focus on treating and reducing symptoms of illness, the recovery model recognises that people can live meaningful, fulfilling lives while managing ongoing conditions. Recovery is defined by the person, not clinical measures.
unistructural.rubric: Identifies one meaningful difference with explanation

multistructural.stem: List FIVE domains included in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social and emotional wellbeing frameworks.
multistructural.modelResponse: Five domains are: connection to body (physical wellbeing), connection to mind (mental and emotional wellbeing), connection to family (kinship relationships), connection to community (social relationships and belonging), and connection to Country (relationship with land, waterways, and all living things).

relational.stem: Explain how structural stigma and self-stigma interact to create barriers to mental health help-seeking.
relational.modelResponse: Structural stigma and self-stigma create a reinforcing cycle. Structural stigma, embedded in policies like discriminatory insurance coverage or employment practices, sends social signals that people with mental health conditions are less valued or capable. Individuals internalise these messages, developing self-stigma - believing they are indeed less capable or valuable. This self-stigma reduces their likelihood of seeking help because they may feel undeserving of support or fear confirming negative stereotypes. Their reluctance to seek help can worsen outcomes, which may reinforce both their own negative self-perception and societal stereotypes. Meanwhile, structural barriers continue operating regardless of whether individuals seek help - even those who overcome self-stigma face practical barriers from discriminatory policies. The interaction means that addressing only self-stigma (through individual interventions) or only structural stigma (through policy change) is insufficient; both must be addressed simultaneously.
relational.rubric: Shows clear understanding of how structural and self-stigma interact in a reinforcing system

extendedAbstract.stem: Drawing on conceptualisations of mental health, stigma theory, and social determinants frameworks, propose how mental health services might be redesigned to address both individual and structural determinants of mental health while respecting diverse cultural frameworks.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
Redesigning mental health services to address multiple determinants while respecting cultural diversity would require fundamental transformation. Structurally, services would need to move beyond individual treatment to become community development partners - advocating for policy change, supporting community capacity, and addressing social determinants like housing and employment. This might include social prescribing (referring to community resources), structural advocacy (working to change discriminatory policies), and community capacity building (supporting community-led initiatives).

Culturally, services would need to move from 'cultural competence' (provider expertise) to 'cultural safety' (defined by communities). This means genuine power-sharing with Indigenous and culturally diverse communities, funding community-controlled services, and recognising diverse conceptualisations of wellbeing. For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, this includes services aligned with SEWB frameworks, addressing colonisation and its ongoing effects, and supporting connection to Country, culture, and community.

Conceptually, services would need to embrace multiple frameworks rather than imposing Western models. The dual continua and recovery approaches could be offered alongside Indigenous and other cultural frameworks, with individuals and communities choosing approaches that resonate. This requires providers willing to work across paradigms and institutional flexibility to accommodate different approaches.

Funding and governance would need reform to enable this transformation. Community-controlled governance could ensure services respond to community-defined needs. Funding would need to support structural advocacy and community development, not just individual treatment. Evaluation would need to include community-defined outcomes, not just clinical measures.

This redesign faces significant challenges: existing professional paradigms, funding structures, and institutional inertia. But without transformation, mental health services will continue primarily treating individuals while leaving structural and cultural determinants unaddressed.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises multiple theoretical frameworks into coherent system redesign with attention to implementation challenges and multiple dimensions
